title: GS - TransUNet: Integrated 2D Gaussian Splatting and Transformer UNet for Accurate Skin Lesion Analysis
author: Anand Kumara (University of California, San Diego), Kavinder Roghit Kanthena (University of California, San Diego), Josna Johna (University of California, San Diego)
background: Developing a dual-task framework that simultaneously classifies and segments skin lesions in dermoscopic images to enhance early skin cancer detection.
contribution: GS - TransUNet introduces a unified approach combining 2D Gaussian splatting and Transformer UNet architecture to enhance automated skin cancer diagnosis, achieving improved segmentation and classification performance.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods typically focused on either segmentation or classification independently, limiting efficiency and effectiveness.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work integrates both tasks into a single model, enhancing robustness and accuracy through a combined loss strategy and innovative mask generation.

key_innovation: The unique integration of Gaussian splatting with a Transformer UNet architecture allows for better handling of local and global features in skin lesions.
real_world_impact: This model has the potential to significantly enhance the accuracy and speed of skin cancer diagnosis, improving patient outcomes and supporting dermatological practices.
limitations: Challenges remain in accurately segmenting irregular lesion shapes due to the inherent biases of the Gaussian splatting method.

new_terms.Gaussian Splatting: **Gaussian Splatting** is a technique for generating segmentation masks by modeling shapes using Gaussian functions to improve boundary precision.
new_terms.Transformer UNet: **Transformer UNet** combines convolutional neural networks with transformer layers to enhance the understanding of spatial relationships in image data.
